Sentence: Consider that there are myriad varieties of natural pest control measures used by organic-certified farms including oil-based suffocants, which - granted - are a fair bit more expensive than conventional pesticides, but work equally well.
Most supermarket/greengrocer tomatoes are grown in hydroponic systems in sealed greenhouses or similar constructions, which are closed-off against pests.
These facilities are regularly sprayed and controlled, whether by organic or non-organic means.
Especially in the U.S. tomatoes (among other foods) are being irradiated, with the 'intention' of reducing food poisoning and rendering larvae and eggs inert.
Remember, you are paying a premium for organic food because of the absence of synthetic fertilisers, chemical sprays, insecticides and pesticides, among other measures.
Nevertheless, organic foods are generally still sprayed for the sake of crop preservation, with substances on an 'permitted' list.

Let's not forget that humans have successfully cultivated crops without synthetics for thousands of years, using 'natural' methods (such as mesh bags) that we are beginning to see a resurgence in use with avid home gardeners.

Verbatim from: <URL>" HOW TO AVOID CONSUMING GMO’S WHEN EATING OUT: Unless labeled or listed organic (or from a reputable local farm the restaurant can verify doesn’t use GMO seeds or feed), I suggest avoiding these 8 genetically modified (GM) foods when dining out: Corn Soy Sugar (beet sugar – i.e.

refined sugar) Papayas (from Hawaii) Canola Cotton (cottonseed oil) Dairy (conventional American cow’s milk and cheese) Zucchini/Yellow Squash Conventional Meat (They are fed GM corn & soy) GM corn, soy and canola oil are the cheapest for restaurants to purchase.
Ask your server about the oils they use to make your food – this is where GMOs are hidden in almost everything from salad dressings to soups to pan or deep fried items.
Know the exceptions: Ask if the cheese is imported.
A cheese from France means you are safe from rbGH – genetically engineered growth hormone and genetically modified ingredients, as this country has banned GMOs all together.

Look out for these hidden GM ingredients: Amino Acids, Aspartame, Ascorbic Acid, Sodium Ascorbate, Vitamin C, Citric Acid, Sodium Citrate, Flavorings (“natural” and “artificial”), High Fructose Corn Syrup, Hydrolyzed Vegetable Protein, Lactic Acid, Maltodextrins, Molasses, Monosodium Glutamate, Sucrose, Textured Vegetable Protein (TVP), Xanthan Gum, Vitamins, Yeast Products.

Unless the sugar they use to make desserts is 100% pure cane, it’s likely from GM sugar beets Consider having the Non-GMO Shopping Guide in your purse or pocket that has a list of GM ingredients that you want to avoid and give it to your waiter or even call ahead.
If more people did this, maybe restaurants would start to pay more attention to the products they buy.
Non-GMO Shopping Guide: <URL>"
Well, the name "organic", for one.
The organic rules were designed by large agribusinesses, imposing overhead requirements that small farmers find it hard to meet.

And conversely, they allow processes that the founders of the organic movement find abhorrent: overcrowding, monoculture, poor nutrition safety created by extreme isolation rather than by care for the animals.
And that's just in the term "organic".
Among conventional farmers, animals are subjected to abusive treatments, even worse diets, antibiotics, hormones; plants are genetically modified and sprayed with toxic chemicals.

And these processes are in fact subsidized, even for extremely wealthy agribusinesses, so that farmers wanting to practice more responsible farming (both for health and the environment) have their prices undercut by government support, as if the government were trying to drive the out of business.

Suggest finding a local grower/farmer who will sell you their organic fruit and vegetables - and hopefully their grass-fed, free-range meat and poultry too.
Or they can recommend someone who can.
Your local grower is likely to have less mark up on their organic goods than the big stores and they will probably provide delivery as well, which is saving you even more money.
I agree with Sarah's comment, stay away from packaged food if you can, it has overheads attached and so the price goes up.
And planning is key, especially when it comes to storage and figuring out how long you have to use the produce before it loses its freshness.
You want to maximise the life of your organic stash.
Planning reduces wastage and helps your food purchase go further.
Also think about the old fashioned barter system.
Do you have a business that sells a product or service your local farmer may exchange for produce, e.g.
hairdresser, accountant, clothing retailer?
My sister is a hairdresser who exchanges haircuts for things like fresh eggs from her neighbour's hen house, home grown tomatoes and weekly house cleaning.
tl;dr: Absolutely on meat and eggs, possibly on dairy products, probably not on vegetables, and no way in hell on TV dinners.
"Organic" is, unfortunately, something of a misnomer at this point.
"Organic" is, unfortunately, something of a misnomer at this point.

The federal rules for "organic" allow all sorts of dubious behavior, while prohibiting the use of "organic" labels on foods that are actually better and more nutritious because they can't comply with rules designed for vast agribusinesses.
An organic vegetable is largely indistinguishable from a conventionally-grown one.
An organic vegetable is largely indistinguishable from a conventionally-grown one.
An organic vegetable is largely indistinguishable from a conventionally-grown one.
It's still grown in vast monocultures, far away from where you live, in varieties designed to ship well and look like a Platonic ideal of the vegetable.
They are still subjected to pesticides and fertilizers.

The "natural" nature of the fertilizers may give them a faint chance of being more tasty than those grown with chemical fertilizers (which are reductionist and may deprive plants of some things they need to develop full flavor), but I suspect few people can spot the difference.
However, many people prefer them for non-taste reasons.
The pesticides they're subjected to are less effective, so they need to use more rotation and other techniques to avoid predators.
The pesticides they're subjected to are less effective, so they need to use more rotation and other techniques to avoid predators.
This dumps less dangerous pesticides into the environment and may be safer for workers.
This dumps less dangerous pesticides into the environment and may be safer for workers.
If you want better flavor, however, you pick vegetable varieties grown to taste good rather than to ship.
That usually means eating locally, which implies seasonally.
It's also unlikely to be organic, since that would forbid ever using any chemical fertilizers or pesticides, leaving land fallow for years that local farmers can't afford.
But it's going to be tastier, and probably healthier despite the occasional use of chemical pesticides (if done judiciously).
But it's going to be tastier, and probably healthier despite the occasional use of chemical pesticides (if done judiciously).
The differences with animal products are more noticeable.
Animals packed in conventionally have to be given huge amounts of antibiotics to keep them from dying.
Animals packed in conventionally have to be given huge amounts of antibiotics to keep them from dying.
These crowded conditions yield bland meat and eggs, and are an ethical nightmare.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
But the food is still limited in variety, and the difference between the "organically" grown mass-produced grain and conventional is probably undetectable.
But the food is still limited in variety, and the difference between the "organically" grown mass-produced grain and conventional is probably undetectable.
But the food is still limited in variety, and the difference between the "organically" grown mass-produced grain and conventional is probably undetectable.
But the food is still limited in variety, and the difference between the "organically" grown mass-produced grain and conventional is probably undetectable.
You will notice the difference with eggs, absolutely.
The meat will be slightly more flavorful.
It should be noticeable in milk, but organic milk is generally subjected to a different pasteurization process.
The difference in processes will make a more noticeable flavor change than the underlying product.
The more processed the food is, the less the difference matters because it's been so thoroughly modified from its original state.
An organic TV dinner tastes of "processed" rather than "organic".
As before, cooking it yourself (or having it cooked fresh) will make a bigger difference.
Yes, organic food tastes the way the earth intended it.
In which case, it is natural, and better for you on all levels.
The taste of organic fruits and vegetables s the most natural thing you can taste.
The question reminds me of another question "Why do we have a double blind trial in science".
Lets apply that logic here.
Scenario 1: Take identical looking organic fruit(say apple) and non-organic fruit.
Remove their labels and put them on a table.
Ask people to taste it.
See how many people rate organic apple as better tasting.
Scenario 2 : Again take identical looking organic and non-organic fruit(apple again!)
and this time switch their labels.
Ask people to taste it.
See how many people rate the 'organically labelled' apple ( which is non-organic actually) better tasting.
Scenario 3 : Repeat scenario 1 but this time ask people if they can identify the organic fruit.
Look for correct response.
Expected Result: If 9 out of 10 can correctly give any identification of better taste of organic food, we have a winner.
Else it's just another MYTH.
So now the question is have such studies been done?
Not with organic food, but switching labels studies have been done with wine, soda etc extensively.
Ref: 'You Are Not So Smart': Why We Can't Tell Good Wine From Bad In short: There is no evidence that organic food tastes better than non-organic ones.
Ref: 'You Are Not So Smart': Why We Can't Tell Good Wine From Bad In short: There is no evidence that organic food tastes better than non-organic ones.
It makes much more of a difference how the food was grown.
There are ranches that produce grass-fed beef but don't go through the rigorous requirements to get the organic label.
That's going to produce a bigger taste difference from typical supermarket beef than organic beef that's been finished (fattened) on organic corn.
Similar deal goes for milk.
Almost no milk intended for drinking, organic or otherwise, uses rBGH.
So the difference is the use of medication and organic feed.
Most organic milk comes from cows primarily eating organic grains.
That's going to taste much the same as regular supermarket milk.
But milk from grass-fed cows, whether organic or not, will taste dramatically different.
But milk from grass-fed cows, whether organic or not, will taste dramatically different.
For vegetables, there isn't even a reason to expect any taste difference.
It'll make a much bigger difference buying locally from farmers' markets.
And much of what you get at a farmers' market will be excellent but not organic, because compliance with the organic regime can be prohibitively expensive for a small farmer.
"Organic" has a very specific definition.
Some organic products happen to also be locally-grown, grass-fed, etc.
But such things are hardly required, and the big organic producers actually run quite similarly to their conventional counterparts.
I usually avoid subjective questions but I will make an exception for this one.

It is important to distinguish officially accredited Organic produce, a label that is usually given only after on-site checks by external assessors sent by an official accrediting body which reviewed the brand.

Some food products are spuriously labelled, 'organic' which is according to someone's opinion could be just home-grown in a kitchen garden or by someone who does not use pesticides on the actual food itself but use pesticides directly or indirectly in the garden or that their neighbours do.

See my answer to this question: Are naturally-derived pesticides as harmful to one's health as synthetically-produced pesticides?
The summary is that "organic" and "synthetic" have nothing to do with safety.
Each chemical must be evaluated separately.
Also remember that synthetically derived versions of organic chemicals, since they are identical, are equally safe.
Hence the lack of any meaning to the phrase "no artificial flavors," since the natural flavors aren't any safer or riskier.
I give an example of Roundup, an herbicide that leaves no residue on plants (safe to eat) but can cause minor eye irritation.

The organic alternative, Pharm Solutions Weed Pharm, is corrosive, can cause permanent eye damage, causes skin sensitization, and is FATAL if swallowed or absorbed through the skin… but also leaves no residue.
Both are equally harmless to the consumer!
Again, each compound must be studied independently.
Fortunately, someone else has done that work for you.
In the US at least, any non-organic products used are thoroughly tested for safety.
If they caused problems for the consumer they wouldn't be legally sold.
So don't fret over pesticides, organic or otherwise, from a health standpoint.
So don't fret over pesticides, organic or otherwise, from a health standpoint.
Focus on food poisoning instead.
tl;dr: A rigid dichotomy between organic and conventional agriculture does not appear to be practical at this time.
tl;dr: A rigid dichotomy between organic and conventional agriculture does not appear to be practical at this time.
A middle path that focuses on convential methods, organic farming as well as low-input or eco-agriculture seems to be the most pragmatic approach at present.
A team of University of Michigan researchers ran two models to try and understand the changes in yield if we were to shift to a solely organic approach.

The first model applied the yield ratio from organic farming for the developed world to the entire planet and the second model applied was more nuanced approach and considered yield rations from both developed and developing nations.

[1] (They based these models on a global dataset of ratios that suggest that organic farming yields less than conventional approaches in the developed world while the opposite is true in the developing world i.e.
yields were boosted.)
"We were all surprised by what we found," said Catherine Badgley, a Michigan paleoecologist who was one of the lead researchers.

The first model yielded 2,641 kilocalories ("calories") per person per day, just under the world's current production of 2,786 calories but significantly higher than the average caloric requirement for a healthy person of between 2,200 and 2,500.

The second model yielded 4,381 calories per person per day, 75 percent greater than current availability-and a quantity that could theoretically sustain a much larger human population than is currently supported on the world's farmland.

This research when read independently appears extrenely heartening however there are some non-trivial challenges that exist if we want to sustain the earth's population solely with organic farming methods.
Sadly this has become a highly politicized issue.
There are fierce proponents of both sides and it difficult to guage what the correct answer is.
In reading about the subject I have come upon contrasting answers from seemingly strong and independent sources; for instance faculty at Harvard, Berkley and the University of Michigan among others.
I'll try to share some of popular arguments and counter-arguments here.

Environmental considerations - The excessive quantities of nitrogen fertilizers used in conventional farms in the United States has resulted in 'dead zones' in the Gulf of Mexico as well as of countries like India, Australia and Brazil.
[2] Stopping the use of fertilizers entirely however is probably not the answer.
Certified organic cropland was about 0.6% of the total U.S. cropland in 2008.
[3] If we were to attempt to switch the other 99+ percent to organic this would require a lot more organic fertiziler i.e.
[3] If we were to attempt to switch the other 99+ percent to organic this would require a lot more organic fertiziler i.e.
This requires a large increase in cattle production and thus a corresponding increase in land for pasture.
The result would ostensibly be mass deforestation.
Not the answer we are looking for.
This helps add some perspective to the assumption that organic farming is perfect for the environment.
There is of course a counter argument here.
Certain researchers have argued that a distinction needs to be made between "green manure and animal manure".
Green manure implies the greater use of notrogen fixing crops and biologically available nitrogen sources like nitrogen fixing bacteria to make up for the dependance on animal manure.
Again, the two arguments are so disparate at present that it is difficult to see which one is true.
Challenges in the developing world - Most of our discussions of organic farming tend to focus on the United States and Europe.
Organic farming and locally grown produce is all the rage all over the United States however this does not always translate to the more impoverished parts of the world.
Technical indicators like production, yield, income and prices need to studied to understand what the best approach to be followed is.
Many impoverished nations use farming methods that lack technology and chemicals not by choice but due to the problems of cost and access.
The ends up being 'organic' due to lack of options.
I head to Eastern Market, a popular farmer's market in Detroit, almost every week.
I absolutely love it.
But try and picture this in countries in Africa and farmers do not have the same access to cities where people are flocking to buy their products at premium prices.
Costs associated with transportation means that they sell their products at low costs and end up surviving at subsistence levels.
There are of course instances of successful adoption of organic farming.
There are of course instances of successful adoption of organic farming.
Studies in the Maikaal district India have shown that cotton yields due to organic farming have been greater than commercial techniques and have benefited the socio-economic status of farmers.
[1] What is the way forward?
The need of the hour seems to be an investment in training and education around the benefits of low-input agriculture as well as organic farming.
We as society need to deromanticize the idea that farming techniques as they were practiced centuries ago is somehow the solution.
The 'local and organic' tag needs to be dropped if we need to head in the right direction.
Organic farming is a relatively sophisticated system that combines age old wisdom with modern innovation.

The even more practical low-input or eco agriculture approach is effectively a middle ground approach that uses many organic farming techniques while using a much smaller percentage of chemicals than conventional techniques.
Unfortunately, answering this question with an actual population figure is difficult to do.
However given the current state of affairs, I believe a best of both worlds approach is necessary.
Note - I am not an expert on the subject, just an arm chair observer.
If there are any glaring errors in my answer please let me know.

In most cases organic crops are only 1/3 the product output of modern conventional farming.
Therefore we need to allocate 3 times the land for the same amount of food.
If conservation of land is considered eco-friendly, then conventional farming wins.
On the other hand, if conventional farmers don't adhere to the proper use of their modern tools like pesticides, herbicides and fertilizer applications, then the ecology will be adversely affected.
Looking more in-depth on fertilizer and comparing the cost of shipping manure and urea as sources of nitrogen, the most important of the nutrients.
A 50 ft long, hi-roof rail car has a maximum capacity of 100 tons.
100 tons of urea will contain 46 tons of nitrogen.
This will fit in the rail car.
Manure, because of it’s low specific gravity of 0.5 so is very bulky, we can only fit 38.46 tons in the rail car.
That equates to 1.15 tons of nitrogen.
It would take 40 rail cars of manure for each car of urea, to get the same amount of nitrogen.
Transportation affects the environment just as bad as anything else.
Those are the things to be included in any equation of comparing organic and conventional farming.
Unfortunately, the proponents of both sides will tend to skew the facts in order to win the debate and the side with the less informed followers usually gain more traction.
In our modern society, it seems the more information there is, is the more people get confused.
There are ways to check facts, but the fact is, that nobody look at dedicated fact-checkers but prefer to go along with any popular rhetoric.

However, when compared to it's alternative, which is industrial farm practices, it does in the form of far lower CO2 emissions and non-polluted soil which also assists in clean water streams and so on.

Your question makes the odd assumptions that more sustainable implies more affordable.
New technologies typically cost more at first, and come down in price over time.

Even if it cost the same to produce an organic head of lettuce as it does to produce a conventional head of lettuce, you would pay more for the value you get from feeling good about your purchasing decisions.

My first reaction to being asked to answer this was to ridicule the question, doubting the premise.
On reflection, however, I can think of a possible explanatory conjecture, requiring someone else's confirmation.
The market for organic eggs is smaller than that for non-organic eggs, which to me implies that the logistical system between producer and consumer would be shorter.
As eggs dwell in the logistics pipeline, their proteins begin to break down and the eggs become watery.
A watery (older, non-organic) egg is less likely to stick to the hot metal of the frying pan than the fresher organic egg with its denser protein.
Perhaps Jonas Luster can debunk or confirm my conjecture.
No, man, you have it completely right.
In addition, non-organic eggs usually come from CAFO in the far north and are cool-chained, which would, even if the distances are the same, change the composition.
Another idea I can't confirm or deny but would make sense is that mass production eggs might have a lower fat and higher protein content due to overfed hens.
The response to this question may differ somewhat by country.
Take the example of Brazil, which has one of the world's largest cattle herds and is one of world's largest beef exporters.

Brahman bull in Avaré, Brazil [Source: Wikimedia Commons, Author: José Reynaldo da Fonseca] Organic beef production in Brazil offers the following tangible environmental benefits (WWF - O que é carne orgânica?
): Producers must comply with environmental legislation, including set asides of legal reserve and areas of permanent preservation on every farm/property, as required by the Brazilian Forest Code.

In addition... Water sources must be protected Use of fire is prohibited in management of pastures Prohibition of use of pesticides and chemicals protects soil and water resources Commercial organic beef production in Brazil has a history of only about 3 years and is still relatively small in scale.

Regarding the land use question, it is important to note: (1) most cattle in Brazil are raised "free-range" (as use of feedlots is limited), although not organically, and (2) there is not a shortage of arable land in Brazil, thus there is not a direct trade-off between grazing cattle (or free-range production of other livestock) and crop cultivation.

Cattle ranching has been linked to deforestation in the Amazon, and Brazilian government policies have been successful in reducing the rate of deforestation in recent years ( Deforestation in the Amazon .)
I analyzed 50 peer-reviewed studies that compared safety aspects of organic and conventional foods for my website, Fact or Fizzle - Questions Answered.
I analyzed 50 peer-reviewed studies that compared safety aspects of organic and conventional foods for my website, Fact or Fizzle - Questions Answered.
Although I did not look specifically for environmental effects (I focused on studies that investigated safety of consuming organics), there were some interesting findings.
Although I did not look specifically for environmental effects (I focused on studies that investigated safety of consuming organics), there were some interesting findings.
Of the 18 studies I found that compared the safety of organic and conventional meats, the evidence in favor of organics was mixed.

However, a number of studies found that organic meats had less antibiotic resistance, which has environmental implications because greater resistance to antibiotics could lead to more dangerous "super-bugs".

However, a number of studies found that organic meats had less antibiotic resistance, which has environmental implications because greater resistance to antibiotics could lead to more dangerous "super-bugs".
At the same time, the research shows that organics tend to have more contaminants, such as e-coli.

Sustainable sounds more intelligent to me, perhaps hand in hand with some of the discussion here: Farming: What are ethical ways to raise animals you intend to kill for food?
It wouldn't be too difficult to advocate de-centralized farming as a method of protecting domestic food sources.
Regionalized farming would reduce transportation costs along with many of the associated negative elements.
The entire economy of food production and land maintenance would re-distribute as well.
Although I think there are valid debates against this concept as an absolute solution, Sustainable livestock production is possible .
I doubt this is a 'new' concept - it seems that is what was common only a hundred years ago back thousands of years.
One person I've heard mentioned as part of the decline in the farming industry in America is Earl Butz , the Secretary of Agriculture under Nixon/Ford who told farmers to 'Get Big, or Get Out.'
This led the way for farm subsidies in corn manufacturing and the associated issues that have arisen from that.
So we can point to the beginning of the current crisis in the food industries to 1971.

The 'organic' label is abused as much as the concept of 'grass-fed' and 'free-range.'

In changing from (or running in parallel) large industrial agriculture to a co-op type of system, our culture could gain the benefits of regional/local farming (employment, boosts to the economy, reduced transportation costs, diversity and quality) while using networking techniques that de-centralize production, processing and storage.
This wouldn't eliminate large-scale industrial ag, but it could enable those industries to modify or improve how they produce.
The two separate systems could end up complimenting each other.
